Award.AwardTitle: Characterizing Paste Microstructure during Setting with Combined Raman Spectroscopy and Confocal Microscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research goal of this project is to enhance our knowledge of cement setting on microstructural level by exploring the dispersion, agglomeration and percolation mechanism of cement particles with advanced physical and chemical imaging methods. To achieve this goal, Raman spectroscopy combined with confocal microscopy will be conducted in real-time on fresh cement pastes. Raman spectroscopy will firstly be applied to both dry cement powder and fresh paste to trace changes in the chemical compositions during early hydration. A Raman library of clinker phases and hydration products will be developed. Then, the Raman spectroscopy will be combined with confocal microscopy to conduct real-time observation on the physical dispersion of particles together with chemical dispersion (chemical mapping) in order to investigate the influence of chemical ingredients and surface chemistry of the particle flocculation. The physical and chemical microstructural parameters will be correlated to the setting time and hydration heat signature using a moving window modeling approach.

The setting and hardening process is considered to be the most critical time period for a concrete structure, during which chemical, physical and mechanical properties of the concrete undergo rapid changes. Remixing, recasting, or replacing cannot be implemented after setting. Thus having solid knowledge about the setting behavior of concrete is essential to guarantee the quality and performance of the material. Concrete setting is governed by paste setting that is caused by the distribution, movement, and connection of cement particles. An in-situ observation of the particle flocculation, agglomeration and percolation processes during the initial hydration period will provide fundamental understanding of paste setting behavior, so that the concrete construction process can be controlled. By combining Raman spectroscopy and confocal microscopy, this proposed work will build up a database on early-age hydration that will be useful to the concrete industry, specifically chemical admixture companies. This database will also be useful for hydration/microstructural development models. Educational plan focuses on training undergraduate and graduate students with better critical thinking and research skills. Outreach activities, such as INSPIRE and E-Expo, are also planned for diverse groups of K-12 students, including minority and female students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposed research aims to characterize microstructure of cement paste during setting by applying an advanced physical and chemical imaging technology: Raman spectroscopy combined with confocal microscopy. The proposed research activities consist of four parts. First, Raman spectroscopy will be applied to dry cement powders and fresh paste specimens to trace the changes in the chemical compositions during hydration. Second, the Raman spectroscopy will be combined with confocal microscopy to in-situ observe the particles’ physical dispersions together with chemical dispersion (chemical mapping). This will help to investigate the influences of chemical ingredients and surface chemical on particle flocculation. Third, a series of complementary experiments on both micro and macro levels will be conducted. The test results, such as surface charges, will be correlated to Raman measurements, so that the accuracy of Raman measurement can be guaranteed. Fourth, the obtained physical and chemical microstructural parameters will be correlated to setting time and heat signature. A moving window modeling approach will be adopted.

In the past year, a Raman database for cement cliner phases and hydration products has been developed. Raman spectroscopy has been used to trace the in-situ hydration progress sucessfully. A quanlitative method was developed to anaylize the degree of hydration based on Raman measurement. This measuring technique has been extensively used on ordinary cement paste, ultra-high performance cement paste, cement pastes containing recycled powders, and gypsum powders used to make cement. A protocol for chemical mapping has been developed. Pastes with different water-to-cement ratios were studied. Dispersion of different phases in hydrating pastes were observed qualitatively. Preliminary results have been published in technical journals and conference proceedings.

The research finds Raman spectroscopy is very sensitive to ingredients used in a cement paste. In ultra-high performance cement paste (UHPC), Raman can clearly differentiate three silica phases (silica sand, silica flour, and silica fume). It is also a very effective method to detect the hydration progress and mechanism in cement. By comparing ordinary cement paste and UHPC paste, the obtained Raman spectra show a clear reduce of the CH amount in UHPC paste that was caused by the pozzonalic reaction. By using the silica flour and silica sand as two references, a quantitative method was developed to trace the degree of hydration in UHPC. The Raman analysis also shows that lots of low density C-S-H would form around recycled powders in a paste with construction demolition wastes. This helps to support and promote the usage of recycled materials in construction.

For chemical mapping, it shows that the dispersion of each phase in cement paste vary a lot during the hydration process. Ettringite tends to clump on the surface of unhydrated phases, which may cause particle agglomoration. CH, on the other hand, tends to cluster in air voids. CH is the only pure phase that can be measured during the mapping process. A hyperbolic hydration model has also been developed based on quantitative analysis of chemical mapping.

Based on the research finds,7 journal papers and 4 conference paper were
published. 6 presentations were given.
